questions.text: What is the main motivation for applying image processing to ultrasound images?

options.C: Enhance real anatomy while suppressing speckle noise

questions.explanation: The slide "The Challenge – Noise vs. Signal" states the goal is to enhance the signal (real anatomy) while suppressing noise caused by speckle.

questions.text: Why is speckle considered both a problem and an opportunity?

options.A: It reduces contrast but improves resolution
options.B: It is hardware noise but easy to remove
options.C: It degrades image appearance but encodes tissue motion
options.D: It only appears in Doppler imaging

questions.explanation: Slides explicitly state the shift: "Speckle is noise → remove it" versus "Speckle is information → track it."

questions.text: What is the key limitation of simple spatial mean filtering in ultrasound?
questions.explanation: The slide on Mean Filters lists the main disadvantage as "Severe blurring" that destroys fine details and edges.

questions.text: Why is the Gaussian filter preferred over the mean filter?

options.C: It weights nearby pixels more strongly

questions.explanation: The Gaussian filter slide explains that pixels closer to the center are weighted more, leading to smoother results than the mean filter.

questions.text: What is the key insight behind Non-Local Means (NLM) filtering?

options.C: Similar textures repeat across the image

questions.explanation: The NLM slide states that similar tissue textures repeat throughout the ultrasound image, even at distant locations.

questions.text: How do weights differ between mean filtering and NLM filtering?

options.A: Mean uses patch similarity, NLM uses distance
options.C: Mean uses spatial distance, NLM uses patch similarity

questions.explanation: The lecture explicitly contrasts mean filtering (spatial distance) with NLM (patch similarity regardless of distance).

questions.text: Why are wavelet filters effective for ultrasound denoising?

options.A: They blur the entire image uniformly
options.B: They separate structure from detail components

questions.explanation: Wavelet slides explain that low frequencies contain anatomy (LL) while high frequencies contain edges and noise.

questions.text: In wavelet denoising, how is speckle noise typically represented?
questions.explanation: The lecture states that noise appears as small, random coefficients in the high-frequency sub-bands.

questions.text: What is speckle tracking primarily used to estimate?
questions.explanation: The speckle tracking definition slide states it provides motion vectors and deformation (strain).

questions.text: Why does simple Sum of Absolute Differences (SAD) fail in ultrasound tracking?

options.B: Sensitive to gain and attenuation changes

questions.explanation: The SAD slide explains that brightness changes due to gain and attenuation cause false mismatches.

questions.text: What is the key advantage of Normalized Cross-Correlation (NCC)?
questions.explanation: The NCC slide states it matches shape rather than absolute brightness and is robust to gain changes.

questions.text: Why is NCC more suitable than SAD for medical ultrasound?

options.C: Robust to speckle and brightness variation

questions.explanation: The comparison table explicitly concludes: "Use NCC for Medical Speckle Tracking."

questions.text: What does Global Longitudinal Strain (GLS) measure?
questions.explanation: The GLS slide explains that myocardial fibers shorten longitudinally during contraction.

questions.text: Why can speckle tracking detect arterial stiffness before plaques are visible?
questions.explanation: The arterial stiffness slide emphasizes tracking tiny radial expansion before visible plaques form.

questions.text: What is the main challenge of out-of-plane motion in ultrasound?

options.B: 2D probes cannot directly observe the elevational axis

questions.explanation: The lecture states that standard 2D probes cannot "see" motion along the Z-axis.

questions.text: How is out-of-plane motion estimated using speckle decorrelation?
questions.explanation: The speckle decorrelation slide explains correlation decays deterministically as scatterers leave the resolution cell.

questions.text: Why is speckle decorrelation often approximated as Gaussian?

options.C: Fully developed speckle exhibits Gaussian decay

questions.explanation: The lecture explicitly notes that for fully developed speckle, correlation decay is approximated as Gaussian.

questions.text: Why is speckle tracking preferred over segmentation for robotic ultrasound control?

options.B: Lower computational cost and stable texture

questions.explanation: Slides state organs are hard to segment in real-time, but speckle provides a stable fingerprint.

questions.text: What is the main goal of feature extraction filters in ultrasound?
questions.explanation: The feature extraction slide states the goal is to highlight structures hard to see with the naked eye.

questions.text: Why is the Sobel filter preferred over simple gradient filters?
questions.explanation: The Sobel slide explains it combines Gaussian smoothing with differentiation to reduce noise sensitivity.

questions.text: What type of structures are Gabor filters particularly suited for in ultrasound?
questions.explanation: The lecture notes Gabor filters are frequently used to detect needles due to their directional texture.

questions.text: Why does Frangi filtering outperform edge detection for vessels?

options.C: Detects tubular structures via Hessian eigenvalues

questions.explanation: The Frangi slide explains it analyzes curvature using Hessian eigenvalues to identify tubes.

questions.text: Which eigenvalue pattern indicates a tubular structure in Frangi filtering?
questions.explanation: The lecture states for vessels: |λ1| ≈ 0 and |λ2| ≫ 0 (negative curvature).

questions.text: Why do standard algorithms fail in acoustic shadows?

options.C: They track noise instead of signal

questions.explanation: The confidence map slide states algorithms fail because they treat shadow pixels as valid.

questions.text: What does a confidence map represent?
questions.explanation: Confidence maps assign values from 0 (unreliable) to 1 (reliable).

questions.text: What is the intuition behind random walks for confidence estimation?

options.B: Simulate beam propagation from the probe

questions.explanation: The slide explains virtual particles travel from the transducer through tissue.

questions.text: Why does confidence drop behind strong reflectors?
questions.explanation: Strong reflectors block beam propagation, leading to acoustic shadows.

questions.text: How are confidence maps used in optimization problems?

options.C: As weighting matrices in the cost function

questions.explanation: The slide shows minimizing confidence-weighted error instead of raw error.

questions.text: What is a major challenge for deep learning in ultrasound?
questions.explanation: The challenges slide lists data scarcity, high noise, and lack of standardization.

questions.text: Why is ultrasound particularly difficult for generalization in AI models?
questions.explanation: Slides highlight poor generalization due to limited understanding of ultrasound physics.

questions.text: What advantage do foundation models bring to ultrasound analysis?
questions.explanation: The UltraSAM slide shows leveraging large open-access datasets.

questions.text: Why are skip connections important in U-Net architectures?
questions.explanation: The U-Net slide states skip connections conserve fine details.

questions.text: Which application best illustrates confidence-driven robotic ultrasound?
questions.explanation: The lecture describes confidence-driven control to ignore unreliable shadow regions.

questions.text: Why is ultrasound especially suited for robotic visual servoing?
questions.explanation: The lecture emphasizes real-time ultrasound for robotic motion compensation.

questions.text: What is the overarching message of this lecture?

options.C: Combining physics, image processing, and AI enables robust ultrasound applications

questions.explanation: The lecture consistently integrates physics, filtering, tracking, confidence modeling, and AI.
